bibl.title: Letter from Frank B. Rogers to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1954

div1.p: Rogers describes an account from the 1895 minutes of the Clinico-Pathological Society of Washington that consistently cites Reed's name incorrectly.

div1.head: Letter from Frank B. Rogers to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1954
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
* UNITED STATES OF AMERICA *
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE DIRECTOR
ARMED FORCES MEDICAL LIBRARY
7TH STREET AND INDEPENDENCE AVENUE SW.
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
MEDEL - D
23 February 1954
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
As I mentioned to you the other night, I found a new account of a
minor episode in the life of Walter Reed while going through the manuscript
minutes-books of the Clinico-Pathological Society of Washington recently.

In the minutes of a meeting held in Washington in February 1895, a
guest speaker at one of the meetings of the Society is repeatedly and con-
sistently referred to as “Dr. Harvey Reed of the U. S. Army.” His remarks,
and the discussion stimulated by them, are given in considerable detail.
The interesting thing is that the subject was “An Inquiry into the so-called
lymphoid nodules of the liver in typhoid fever”, and of course it is well
known from other sources that this was the subject on which Walter Reed
was working at Johns Hopkins. It is a wry comment on the nature of fame
that only a few years before the name of Walter Reed was well known to
even the man on the street, his physician colleagues could not get it
straight.

Your offer to give me a head-start on the Reed diary is generous, and
perhaps proves that there is some honor among bibliophiles; it is rare
indeed to have one thief tell another thief where the loot is hidden. If
you will now give me the name and address and a few small details, I will
time-stamp your reply and allow myself one year, after which all rights
in this domain will revert to you. If I succeed, we will gladly pay you
as a brokerage fee the price of one microfilm copy.

I enjoyed seeing you very much. Hope the Havana project works out.
With all the best...
div1.closer:
Aye, Frank Rogers FRANK B. ROGERS
Lt Col, MC
Director
P. S. The minutes of the Clinico-Pathological
Society are now in the hands of Dr. Walter W.
Boyd, who expects to take them to Europe this
August and spend the next year working them
over in preparation of a history of the Society.
F.B.R.
